definition:
A topological space $(X,\tau)$ is said to be $T_1$ (or said to hold the
$T_1$ axiom) if for all distinct points $x,y\in X$ ($x\neq y$), there
exists an open set $U\in\tau$ such that $x\in U$ and $y\notin U$.

A space being $T_1$ is equivalent to the following statements:

-   For every $x\in X$, the set $\{x\}$ is closed.

-   Every subset of $X$ is equal to the intersection of all the open
    sets that contain it.

-   Distinct points are separated.
